unnormalised: **National Highways Authority of India (NHAI) Announces New Toll Rates Effective 15/06/2024**
normalised: **N-H-A-I Announces New Toll Rates Effective fifteenth June two thousand and twenty four**

unnormalised: The NHAI has released a notification confirming revised toll rates across national highways, effective from June 15th, 2024. The average toll increase is approximately 5%, with specific rates varying based on vehicle type and highway section. The adjustment is part of the annual revision linked to the Wholesale Price Index (WPI).
normalised: The N-H-A-I has released a notification confirming revised toll rates across national highways, effective from June fifteenth, two thousand and twenty four. The average toll increase is approximately five percent, with specific rates varying based on vehicle type and highway section. The adjustment is part of the annual revision linked to the Wholesale Price Index (W-P-I).

unnormalised: For cars and jeeps, the toll at the Panipat-Jalandhar stretch (NH-44) will now be Rs. 160, up from Rs. 150. Similarly, commercial vehicles like trucks and buses will see a revised rate of Rs. 550 for a single journey on the Delhi-Agra highway (NH-19). The exact increase depends on the toll plaza and the distance covered.
normalised: For cars and jeeps, the toll at the Panipat-Jalandhar stretch (N-H- forty four) will now be rupee one hundred and sixty, up from rupee one hundred and fifty. Similarly, commercial vehicles like trucks and buses will see a revised rate of rupee five hundred and fifty for a single journey on the Delhi-Agra highway (N-H- nineteen). The exact increase depends on the toll plaza and the distance covered.

unnormalised: Commuters using the Mumbai-Pune Expressway can expect an increase of Rs. 25 for cars, bringing the total toll to Rs. 300. The Chennai-Bangalore highway (NH-48), a crucial route for South India, will also witness a moderate increase of about Rs. 10 for light vehicles.
normalised: Commuters using the Mumbai-Pune Expressway can expect an increase of rupee twenty five for cars, bringing the total toll to rupee three hundred. The Chennai-Bangalore highway (N-H- forty eight), a crucial route for South India, will also witness a moderate increase of about rupee ten for light vehicles.

unnormalised: The NHAI stated that these revisions are crucial for the maintenance and improvement of road infrastructure across the country. The collected toll revenue contributes towards ongoing projects, including widening existing highways, constructing new flyovers, and enhancing road safety measures. The authority is also planning to implement FASTag systems more efficiently to reduce congestion at toll plazas.
normalised: The N-H-A-I stated that these revisions are crucial for the maintenance and improvement of road infrastructure across the country. The collected toll revenue contributes towards ongoing projects, including widening existing highways, constructing new flyovers, and enhancing road safety measures. The authority is also planning to implement F-A-S-T-ag systems more efficiently to reduce congestion at toll plazas.

unnormalised: Motorists are advised to check the updated toll rates on the NHAI website or mobile app before planning their journeys. The new rates will be displayed at all toll plazas. The NHAI has assured the public that these increases are essential to ensure the long-term sustainability and quality of India’s national highways.
normalised: Motorists are advised to check the updated toll rates on the N-H-A-I website or mobile app before planning their journeys. The new rates will be displayed at all toll plazas. The N-H-A-I has assured the public that these increases are essential to ensure the long-term sustainability and quality of India’s national highways.
